text: I often look at things from a “what needs doing” x “what are people good at” x “what do people like/not like doing”. Ideally putting people on the things that need doing AND they’re good at; if you can optimize for what people like/don’t like as well, that’s great, but not required. We all have to do things we don’t like at work sometimes.

elements.text: I often look at things from a “what needs doing” x “what are people good at” x “what do people like/not like doing”. text:
+1 have tried both Sococo as well as an always-on Zoom and it just doesn’t work IMHO (plus it hogs tons of computer resources - if you have a Macbook Air or other lightweight computer, forget getting anything done while your computer tries to cool itself down).

My preference is to set up dedicated time for work meetings, encourage people to meet spontaneously instead of always typing everything out on Slack, and then also have dedicated (optional) time for socializing, whether it’s playing a game or just talking about anything that’s not work.
